author: Helena Horton
title: Sadiq Khan under fire as Londoners call for removal of Khloe Kardashian Underground fitness adverts
text:
P rotein World has once again come under fire for its adverts, this time featuring one of the lesser-known Kardashians.
Feminists have asked London Mayor Sadiq Khan to remove the images over worries they spread negative attitudes towards body image.
After the controversial 2015 advert which came under fire for its "beach body" message, this new advertisement features Khloe Kardashian in a skimpy outfit, with the slogan "can you keep up with a Kardashian?".
On the Protein World website, the Kardashian sister described how getting a "dream body" takes "dedication and literal sweat and tears".
Many have said this is an unhelpful message, especially as the Mayor, who is the father of two teenage daughters, announced adverts which promoted a damaging attitude towards body image would be removed from the tube network.
TfL thinks this advert is acceptable?! Mayor's advertising steering group meeting this week. Hope they'll listen. https://t.co/4eDrAa0hyc 
— Caroline Russell (@CarolineRussell) February 15, 2017 This advert is a total disgrace . Haven't you learnt your lesson @ProteinWorld ? @WEP_UK @RepresentPledge @EverydaySexism pic.twitter.com/j66L0q6iQg 
— Catherine McCormack (@CathMcCormack) January 27, 2017 T he campaign states its aim is to make women feel “more confident and comfortable” in their own skin or “show their ex what he’s missing”. 
TfL told the Evening Standard that the advert would not be covered by the ban, as it doesn't cover all images of people in skimpy clothing.
A spokesman for the Mayor told the paper: “This advert was closely reviewed and deemed to comply with the new TfL advertising policy that bans adverts that could pressurise people to conform to unhealthy or unrealistic body images.”
Sadiq Khan got a bit heated on LBC on subject of his body-shaming Tube advert ban. Insists he hasn’t banned all bikini adverts.
— Adam Bienkov (@AdamBienkov) September 23, 2016 H owever, not everyone agrees. Green councillor Caroline Russell claimed to have had complaints from constituents about the advert.
She told the Standard: "People taking the Tube should not have to be bombarded with adverts that imply their bodies aren’t good enough.
“Young people receive this negative message from enough social media channels and it’s appalling that this is being reinforced on Tube platforms, against the Mayor’s own policy, when people are taking trips to school, to work, or going out to socialise. 
Watch | Sadiq Khan reveals he used to party at Fabric 02:15 “I am urging the Mayor to look again at these adverts that challenge young people to ‘keep up’ with reality stars known for idealised and unrealistic body shapes. He needs to enforce his own guidelines and live up to his manifesto promise to Londoners.
“Every body is a good body and TfL should be promoting inclusion and making their stations welcoming spaces. Allowing these adverts risks making people lose confidence in themselves.”
T he Advertising Standards Agency removed Protein World's controversial "beach body" advert after complaints and protests.
Great response from Dove to the recent ProteinWorld ads #beachbodyready pic.twitter.com/yFTqN31OOE 
— Andrew Bloch (@AndrewBloch) April 29, 2015 I t said at the time: "We've met with Protein World to discuss its "Are you beach body ready?" ad campaign.
"It's coming down in the next three days and, due to our concerns about a range of health and weight loss claims made in the ad, it can't appear again in its current form.
"Although the ad won't appear in the meantime, we've launched an investigation to establish if it breaks harm and offence rules or is socially irresponsible.
"We will now carefully and objectively explore the complaints that have prompted concerns around body confidence and promptly publish our findings."
